This study presents a Pd(II)-anchored polyarylether where numerous nitrogen atoms coordinate with palladium nitrate. The catalyst demonstrated remarkable activity against carbon disulfide at room temperature. Furthermore, the integration of chemically stable polymers and sacrificial agents enhanced the catalyst's renewability. By synthesizing both experimental and theoretical results, we proposed a reaction pathway whereby hydroxyl nucleophiles attacked the C = S bonds, leading to the formation of carbon dioxide. This research offered significant insights into the pivotal role of immobilized palladium in the hydrolysis of carbon disulfide and underscored the potential of polymers in purifying water from contaminants. Graphical abstract Room-temperature hydrolytic cleavage of CS2: This Pd(II)-functionalized polyarylether can complete the activation and hydrolysis of CS2 to produce CO2 through two hydroxide nucleophilic attacks, with a catalytic efficiency of 6.54 μmol/g/h. After 8 cycles, the catalytic efficiency remained above 80 % of the fresh catalyst. Within this realm, porous polymeric materials have shown considerable promise due to their broad pore size distribution, stable covalent frameworks, and customizable catalytic site structures [3,4]. Incorporating transition metals into the polymer framework significantly boosts catalytic efficiency for specific reactions, thus broadening the utility of these organic-inorganic hybrid catalysts [5,6]. Polyarylether (PAE), a distinct type of engineering thermoplastic, is characterized by aryl groups covalently bonded through ether linkages within its polymer backbone. PAE exhibits exceptional stability against solvents, chemicals, and thermal exposure, rendering it highly suitable for diverse applications across multiple sectors, including electronics, biomedicine, nuclear energy, aerospace, and the automotive industry [7]. Its structure readily allows modification with various functional groups, such as cyano, carbonyl, carboxyl, and sulfonyl groups [8,9], thereby enhancing its potential for catalytic applications in environmental chemistry. Carbon disulfide (CS2) is extensively used as a solvent or feedstock in various industrial processes. Atmospheric pollution from CS2, primarily due to industrial waste emissions, poses significant health hazards to humans [10–12]. Naturally occurring CS2 primarily derives from the decomposition of organic materials in soil and oceans, threatening drinking water safety and the survival of microorganisms [13,14]. In the petroleum industry, sulfides in crude oil can cause severe equipment corrosion and deactivate industrial catalysts [15–17]. Over recent decades, several methods for CS2 removal have been developed, including physisorption [10,18], biological oxidation [19,20], and chemical approaches. Although chemical methods are highly effective and versatile, traditional chemical processes incur substantial energy costs and carry risks, such as potential explosions during incineration [21–23]. Catalytic hydrolysis offers a compromise, balancing lower energy consumption with efficient CS2 removal. For instance, Fe2O3 and CuO have been utilized to catalyze the hydrolysis of CS2 into H2S and CO2 at 70 °C [24]. Wu et al. enhanced the hydrolytic activity of K0.1Al2O3 against CS2 through N-doping, achieving an H2S selectivity of 80 % at 150 °C [25]. A significant breakthrough was achieved in 2016 when transition metal palladium-mediated catalysis of small molecule complexes facilitated the hydrolysis and cleavage of CS2 to CO2 at ambient temperature and pressure [26]. Advances in heterogeneous catalysis are expected to improve economic efficiency through better kinetic and recycle values [27–29]. Recently, a Pd(II)-anchored calixarene-based porous organic polymer was developed, leveraging the confined catalytic effects of its pores to facilitate the efficient hydrolytic cleavage and removal of carbon disulfide and carbonyl sulfide [30]. Furthermore, bipyridine and phenanthroline groups were integrated into the porous polymers to serve as coordination sites for palladium, enabling room-temperature desulfurization [31]. Inspired by these, the integration of transition metal palladium coordination structures into common polymers for functionalized polymer-mediated hydrolysis suggests substantial practical application potential for CS2 removal. In this study, a novel polyarylether named PAE-1, featuring hexaazatrinaphthalene (HATN) units, was synthesized via covalent cross-linking. Following this, a palladium(II) complex was incorporated into the polymer backbone using a post-modification approach, producing the palladium-functionalized polyarylether, PAE-2. The catalytic efficacy of PAE-2 in hydrolyzing carbon disulfide and carbonyl sulfur was thoroughly evaluated. A synergistic interaction between the anchored palladium centers and the entrapped CS₂ molecules in the mesoporous structure of PAE-2 promoted the formation of multinuclear catalytic sites. Under the influence of water's nucleophilic activity, both carbon-sulfur bonds in CS₂ were completely hydrolyzed, converting into carbon dioxide and non-toxic sulfur species. Notably, this represents the first instance of utilizing a conventional polymer to facilitate the hydrolytic cleavage of carbon disulfide under mild conditions, as evidenced by previously reported desulfurization catalysts (Table S4). Under ambient conditions (25 °C, atmospheric pressure), PAE-2 demonstrated a carbon disulfide hydrolysis rate of 6.54 μmol/g/h. Additionally, in-situ regeneration of the catalyst was feasible using a suitable oxidant, providing innovative approaches for enhancing desulfurization technology and methodologies. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis procedures of palladium-functionalized polyarylether PEA-2 Detailed methods for synthesizing organic monomers 1 and 2 are described in the supporting information. Following this, the polyarylether PAE-1, incorporating hexaazatrinaphthalene (HATN) units, was synthesized via the Williamson synthesis method (Scheme S3). This structure's abundant pyridine nitrogen atoms acted as coordination sites for further modification. PAE-2 was synthesized by functionalizing PAE-1 with a palladium nitrate solution (Scheme S4), enabling the subsequent post-modification. 2.2 General procedure for catalytic hydrolysis of carbon disulfide In a 2.0 mL reaction flask (actual volume 2.2 mL) equipped with a 3 mm stirrer, 10 mg of the catalyst PAE-2, 100 μL of H₂O, and 50 μL of CS₂ were added. The flask was then sealed with a rubber gasket cap and the mixture was agitated in an incubator set to 25 °C. Gas samples were periodically taken from the reaction flask. Using an SGE 500 μL syringe equipped with an air valve, 500 μL of gas was withdrawn from the flask at each sampling time and injected into a GC or gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) system for analysis (Fig. 1c , Figure S6). 2.3 Detection and calculation of carbon dioxide content The determination of carbon dioxide content was carried out on the basis of previous studies[30,31]. The yield of carbon dioxide, a product of the catalytic reaction, serves as an indicator of catalytic efficiency. The CO₂ production was quantitatively determined using a gas chromatograph GC9790Plus with a TCD detector, which was calibrated using an external standard method with 1 % CO₂ in high-purity helium as the carrier gas. The volume fraction of carbon dioxide in the reactor bottle was measured by GC. Subsequently, the total amount of CO₂ in both the aqueous and gaseous phases was calculated according to Henry's law [32] in supporting information. 2.4 Recovery and regeneration of the heterogeneous catalyst After the reaction, collect the sulfur-containing catalyst and continue stirring to ensure complete reaction for 48 h. Subsequently, wash the catalyst with water and ethanol. Following centrifugal separation, dry the solid under vacuum at 60 °C to obtain the sulfur-containing deactivated catalyst, designated PAE-3. To reactivate the catalyst, mix 50 mg of PAE-3 with 500 μL of nitric acid and incubate at 45 °C for 24 h. After washing with water, dry the catalyst under vacuum at 60 °C to obtain the reactivated catalyst, referred to as Recovered PAE-2. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization of materials The structural composition of PAE-1 was analyzed by elemental analysis (EA) as detailed in Table S1. The elemental composition of PAE-1 was determined to be carbon 59.45 %, hydrogen 3.79 %, and nitrogen 11.22 %. Fig. 2a presents the FT-IR spectrum of the monomers and PAE-1. In this spectrum, the -OH signal peak of Monomer 1 at 3334 cm⁻¹ was notably attenuated. Additionally, the characteristic peaks corresponding to the tensile vibration of CO-C were observed at 1280 cm⁻¹ and 1040 cm⁻¹ in PAE-1 [9], confirming that the covalent cross-linking polymerization reaction was successfully completed. The structure of the polymer was elucidated using solid-state NMR spectroscopy, as shown in Fig. 2b. The peak at 156 ppm is attributed to the distinctive carbon signal associated with the ether bond. Additionally, the peak at 120 ppm corresponds to the unique signal of the C-N bond on the benzene ring. A peak around 110 ppm can be ascribed to the C-C bond signal on the benzene ring, confirming the successful synthesis of PAE-1. Under standard conditions, PAE-1 demonstrated a CO₂ adsorption capacity of 21.3 cm³·g⁻¹ (Figure S7). Subsequently, nitrogen adsorption isotherms were utilized to analyze the pore size characteristics of PAE-1. The polymer's isotherm displayed a type-IV isotherm according to the IUPAC classification (Figure S8), with a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area calculated to be 5.7 m²·g⁻¹. The pore size distribution indicated the presence of mesopores ranging from 2 to 20 nm within the polymer [33]. Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometry (ICP-OES) was employed to quantify the palladium content in the sample PAE-2, which was determined to be 22.24 % (Table S2). To further elucidate the internal crystal structure of the material, X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were conducted (Fig. 2c). Both PAE-1 and PAE-2 showed only one amorphous carbon peak and were identified as amorphous materials. In the XRD pattern of PAE-2, there were no discernible diffraction peaks corresponding to zero-valent palladium [34] or palladium oxide [35]. To further characterize the chemical structure of the polymers, XPS was employed to analyze PAE-1 and PAE-2. PAE-1 was primarily composed of C, N, and O elements. PAE-2, a polymer enriched with Pd, contained carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, and palladium elements, as depicted in Fig. 2d The peak fitting for the palladium element is presented in Fig. 2e. The binding energy for Pd3d5/2 in PAE-2 was recorded at 338.15 eV, indicative of palladium in the +2 oxidation state [36], confirming the formation of a divalent palladium solid catalyst. Furthermore, the C = N binding energy in PAE-2 exhibited a positive shift of 0.13 eV, and a nitrate (NO3 -) signal was observed at 405.51 eV, also corroborated by infrared spectroscopy in Fig. 7c [37]. These findings suggest that the palladium nitrate active metal center was effectively integrated onto the polymer backbone, utilizing nitrogen-containing coordination sites. Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FE-SEM) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) were employed to characterize the morphology and elemental distribution within the polymers. FE-SEM analysis revealed that the polymers are amorphous with a lumpy structure (Fig. 3a –3b). TEM analysis demonstrated the presence of uniform, fine particles within the polymer matrix of PAE-2 following palladium functionalization (Fig. 3c–3d). Elemental mapping confirmed the uniform distribution of the palladium element throughout PAE-2 (Fig. 3e–3h). 3.2 Catalytic performance and proposed mechanism In previous research [26], a series of homogeneous catalysts were synthesized through the coordination reaction between a ligand and palladium nitrate. Under the influence of these small molecule complexes, carbon disulfide was hydrolyzed and decomposed, forming palladium-sulfur intermediates and releasing carbon dioxide. In the current study, palladium nitrate has been successfully integrated with nitrogen-containing units within the polyarylether backbone, thereby embedding palladium nitrate complex catalysts within the polymer structure. This study aimed to explore the catalytic removal of aqueous carbon disulfide using the functionalized polymer, PAE-2. During the expected reaction, carbon disulfide is absorbed into PAE-2 in the aqueous phase through free diffusion and becomes coordinated with Pd(II) atoms. Subsequently, under the nucleophilic action of water molecules, the carbon-sulfur bonds in carbon disulfide are progressively cleaved, resulting in the release of carbon dioxide gas. To ensure that the catalytic process unfolded as expected, various tests were conducted. Initially, control experiments were carried out to confirm the occurrence of catalytic reactions (Table 1 ). This study aimed to investigate the hydrolysis of carbon disulfide under ambient temperature and pressure, where air constituted the initial gas in the reaction vessel. In the absence of additional carbon dioxide production, the carbon dioxide level in the reaction vessel was equivalent to that in ambient air (Entry 1). As indicated by Entries 2 to 5, a notable increase in carbon dioxide content (0.6875 μmol) was only observed when the catalyst, water, and carbon disulfide were combined, substantiating the occurrence of a catalytic reaction. These control experiments aligned with prior studies [26,30] which demonstrated that both carbon disulfide and water are reactants, and that carbon dioxide is a product of the catalytic hydrolysis of carbon disulfide. To further confirm the production of carbon dioxide, gases from the various control groups were analyzed using GC–MS. A significant presence of carbon dioxide, with an m/z of 44, was detected when PAE-2 was mixed with water and carbon disulfide (Fig. 5a). These results verify that the palladium-functionalized polyarylether PAE-2 effectively catalyzes the hydrolysis of carbon disulfide into carbon dioxide at room temperature and pressure, achieving a catalytic rate of 6.54 μmol/g/h over 10.5 h. PAE-1 was employed as a substitute for PAE-2 in the catalytic reaction to better understand the carbon dioxide production process (Entry 6). The findings revealed that PAE-1 exhibited no catalytic activity, underscoring the critical role of palladium nitrate in the structure of PAE-2. A model complex molecule, HATN-Pd-1 (prepared according to the literature [30]), with an equivalent palladium content to PAE-2, served as a catalyst. The results indicated that while the catalytic reaction occurred, the efficiency of PAE-2 was 4.1 times higher than that of the complex. These experiments demonstrated that palladium nitrate, coordinated with nitrogen atoms, constituted the active center for the catalytic reactions. The immobilization of active centers within the polymer chains [38] may mitigate the palladium aggregation induced by metal-metal bonding [39] observed in small molecule complexes, thus enhancing the rate of heterogeneous catalytic reactions in PAE-2. To rule out the influence of palladium in other valence states, palladium in PAE-2 was reduced using a strong reducing agent, hydrazine hydrate (N2H4·H2O) [40], as shown in Figure S21. The reduced catalyst, PAE-Pd(0), exhibited a significant decline in catalytic performance (Fig. 4b ). These findings further confirm that palladium(II)-functionalized polyarylether exhibits exceptional catalytic desulfurization activity. The performance of catalysts with varying palladium nitrate contents was evaluated and compared. As depicted in Fig. 4c, the catalytic efficiency of PAE-2–9 % (containing 9 % palladium) was significantly lower (32.28 μmol/g) than that of PAE-2. This finding suggests that a higher content of palladium nitrate enhances the capture and hydrolysis of carbon disulfide. In experiments using functionalized PAE-1, an increased amount of Pd(NO3)2·2H2O was tested; however, the maximum palladium nitrate content achieved was approximately 22 %. Consequently, all catalysts employed in subsequent reactions maintained a palladium content of 22 % (PAE-2), optimizing their performance. To investigate the influence of temperature on catalytic performance, reaction temperatures were set at 0 °C, 25 °C, and 60 °C. As illustrated in Fig. 4d, the catalytic rates over 10.5 h were 0.67 μmol/g/h, 6.54 μmol/g/h, and 23.69 μmol/g/h, respectively, indicating that an increase in temperature accelerates the reaction. The occurrence of catalytic activity at low temperatures demonstrates that PAE-2 possesses exceptional temperature adaptability, facilitating the removal of carbon disulfide from water without the need for additional energy. This establishes a greener, less energy-intensive approach for desulfurization, contrasting with most other catalysts that require high temperatures to hydrolyze carbon disulfide or carbonyl sulfur [41,42] (Table S4). When carbon disulfide undergoes cleavage of only one C = S bond, COS is formed. COS is slightly more hydrolyzable than carbon disulfide, which contains two C = S bonds [42]. COS gas was synthesized using potassium thiocyanate and concentrated sulfuric acid [30]. The catalytic performance of PAE-2 towards carbonyl sulfur was evaluated under ambient temperature and atmospheric pressure. The results demonstrated that the catalytic efficiency reached 27.24 μmol/g/h after 10.5 h (Fig. 4e). After >60 h of catalytic reaction, the mixture's solids were separated, and the resulting PAE-3 was found to be incapable of further catalysis, indicating complete inactivation of the catalyst. Subsequently, nitric acid was introduced to the reactants, and it was observed that carbon dioxide production could resume (Fig. 4f). This suggests that nitric acid may reactivate the deactivated catalyst. When nitric acid was added as a sacrificial agent to the reaction, the catalytic efficiency significantly increased to 34.09 μmol/g/h (Fig. 4a), which is 5.2 times higher than under standard conditions without nitric acid. In the absence of carbon disulfide, the catalyst did not produce carbon dioxide in the presence of nitric acid (Table 1, Entry 11). These results confirm that HNO₃, acting as a sacrificial agent, can reactivate the catalyst and enhance hydrolysis, thereby improving catalytic efficiency. To determine the origin of carbon dioxide in catalytic products, isotope labeling was utilized. As demonstrated in Figure 5a, 18O-labeled carbon dioxide (C18O2, m/z = 48) was detected by GC–MS when heavy oxygen water (H2 18O) was used, confirming that the oxygen in the carbon dioxide originated from hydrolysis. Additionally, it was observed that the original intermediate, carbonyl sulfur (COS, m/z = 60), was replaced by 18O-labeled carbonyl sulfur (C18OS, m/z = 62). In the absence of carbon disulfide or catalyst in the reaction system, neither carbonyl sulfur nor carbon dioxide was detected. These experiments substantiated the reaction pathway of CS2+H2O→COS→CO2. In other studies, hydrogen sulfide (H2S, m/z = 34) was reported as a hydrolysis product of carbon disulfide [24,43]; however, it was not detected in our catalytic system, suggesting that the sulfur atom follows a different path. To track the fate of hydrogen atoms from water, the pH of the reaction solution was monitored in real-time using a pH meter (Fig. 5b ). It was observed that as the reaction progressed, the concentration of hydrogen ions in the solution gradually increased, and the pH decreased from 4.77 to 4.18, indicating that the hydrogen atoms in the water were converted into protons. In order to better understand the catalytic mechanism of palladium, a series of comparative catalytic experiments were carried out. Firstly, A hot filtration experiment after 4 h reaction (Fig. 6a ) was conducted to demonstrate heterogeneous catalytic properties. The reaction ceased immediately after Pd catalyst’s removal, and ICP analysis of the filtrate was only 0.621 ppb Pd (Table S2), confirming no leaching. These results strongly support heterogeneous catalysis. Furthermore, some other functionalized polymers with different Lewis metals were prepared using similar synthesis steps to PAE-2. The amount of metal salt used in the preparation was consistent with the palladium nitrate in PAE-2. These reference materials were named PAE-Fe(NO3)3, PAE-Cu(NO3)2, PAE-AlCl3 and PAE-PdCl2, respectively. Under the same reaction conditions, these catalysts showed negligible catalytic effects (<10 μmol/g in 10.5 h, Fig. 6b). This fully demonstrated the particularity of palladium nitrate in this work. These results suggest that the role of Pd was not purely electronic, but involves unique Pd-S interactions. To confirm whether other acids can promote catalytic reactions in the same way as nitric acid, hydrochloric acid and sulfuric acid with the same concentration of hydrogen ions were first added (Fig. 6c). The results showed that catalytic efficiency (<20 μmol/g) was much lower than that of nitric acid (359.23 μmol/g). This proved that nitric acid did not facilitate the catalytic reaction by donating protons. Secondly, when sodium nitrate with the same amount of nitrate ions was added, the catalytic efficiency was also not improved (<12.27 μmol/g). This proved that nitric acid did not only facilitate catalytic reactions by providing nitrate ions. When no palladium catalyst was used, nitric acid alone proved incapable of catalyzing the hydrolysis of carbon disulfide. This proved that nitric acid needed to work synergistically with a palladium catalyst. The catalytic effects at different acids and at different concentrations of acids were also supplemented (Fig. 6d). First, nitric acid and hydrochloric acid at a concentration of 7.6 M were configured, respectively. Change the amount of acid solution while keeping the total volume of water and acid solution in the reaction constant (150 μl). As a result, with the decrease of the volume of nitric acid, the catalytic efficiency gradually decreased from 445.37 μmol/g to 287.61 μmol/g. This proved that higher concentrations of nitric acid (stronger oxidation) were more effective in facilitating the reaction. Considering that nitric acid may corrode the test instrument, a moderate concentration of nitric acid was selected for this work (50 μL 7.6 M HNO3). In addition, when the same concentration of non-oxidizing acid was used instead, hydrochloric acid showed inhibition to the catalytic effect. When the least volume of hydrochloric acid was used (25 μL), the catalytic effect was the highest, which was only 43.71 μmol/g. This proved once again that nitric acid did not facilitate catalytic reactions by providing protons. Conversely, protons may inhibit catalytic reactions to some extent. Nitric acid, as a sacrificial agent, facilitated the catalytic reaction by restoring the inactivated palladium site, which was achieved by oxidative cleavage of the Pd-S coordination bond and subsequent supply of nitrate ions. To study the mechanism of inactivation, kinetic data for palladium sulfide formation were obtained by XPS quantitative analysis. As shown in Fig. 6e, catalysts at different time of the reaction were filtered separated and immediately subjected to XPS analysis. The results showed that the sulfur content in the catalyst solids increased gradually with the extension of the participation reaction time. The sulfur content was 0.38 % after 2 h of reaction and 1.69 % after 10.5 h of further reaction. Correspondingly, the catalytic rate gradually slowed down as the reaction time increases. This established a negative correlation between palladium sulfide formation and catalytic rate, showing that the introduction of sulfur was accompanied by the deactivation of the catalyst. In order to exclude the generation of hydrogen sulfide, the lead acetate dipstick method was used for testing. When wetted with deionized water, these commercial test strips react with H₂S at concentrations in excess of 5 ppm, causing the color to change from white to black immediately. As shown in Fig. 6f, the white lead acetate test strip was inserted into the reaction flask (after 10.5 h’ of reaction), held for 30 s, and then removed. The lead acetate test strips did not turn black, which proved that no hydrogen sulfide was produced. Besides, gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) confirmed that no H₂S (m/z = 34) was produced (Fig. 5a). Considering the coordination reaction between sulfur atoms in CS₂ and palladium atoms in the catalyst, it was hypothesized that sulfur atoms from CS₂ bind to the palladium during the reaction, progressively poisoning the catalyst. This interaction is believed to lead to the gradual deactivation of the catalyst, culminating in the complete inactivation of PAE-3, which was thoroughly characterized for this reason. XPS quantitative analysis (Table S3) revealed that PAE-3 contained 1.69 % elemental sulfur, absent in PAE-2. Elemental mapping confirmed the uniform distribution of sulfur and palladium post-catalysis (Fig. 5c–5e). The chemical environments of sulfur and palladium were further elucidated through XPS narrow spectrum analysis. The binding energy of S2p3/2 at 162.25 eV, attributed to a S-Pd- bond [44] (Fig. 7a ), indicated that sulfur atoms in PAE-3 were bonded to palladium atoms. No other sulfur species such as sulfate were found because of the strong coordination of the palladium atoms on the sulfur atoms [26,30,31]. Additionally, the palladium binding energy shifted negatively to 336.99 eV (Fig. 7b) compared to PAE-2, suggesting a change in the chemical environment of palladium. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy also showed a notable reduction in the nitrate signal for PAE-3 (Fig. 7c). These characterizations demonstrated that sulfur ions replaced the nitrate in the catalyst. To investigate the ultimate fate of sulfur in the catalytic process, a solution of PAE-3 reacting with nitric acid was analyzed. The presence of sulfate ions was confirmed by adding barium chloride to the solution, which resulted in the formation of a white precipitate. This precipitate was identified as barium sulfate through XRD and FT-IR [45] (Fig. 5f–5 g). These findings demonstrate that during the catalytic hydrolysis and catalyst activation process, the sulfur atoms initially coordinate with palladium and are subsequently oxidized to sulfate. Following the oxidation and activation with nitric acid, the chemical structure of the catalyst PAE-2 was restored. In the recovered PAE-2, sulfur content was reduced to 0.25 % (Table S3), and the palladium binding energy was observed to increase as the same of PAE-2 (Fig. 7a–7b). Infrared spectroscopy further revealed an enhanced nitrate signal (Fig. 7c). These findings demonstrate that nitric acid, acting as a sacrificial agent, effectively broke the palladium-sulfur bonds (PAE-3) and restored the catalyst's original structure (PAE-2). Due to the heterogeneity of the polymer catalyst, the reaction mixture could be separated through simple filtration. The collected PAE-3 was reactivated to PAE-2 by nitric acid activation. This process greatly simplifies catalyst recycling compared to small-molecule homogeneous catalysts. Based on the above analysis and previous research [26,30], a proposed mechanism (Fig. 7e) involves the catalysis of CS₂ hydrolysis by palladium-functionalized polyarylether (PAE-2), activated by nitric acid. Initially, the water molecule and carbon disulfide coordinated with palladium (Int 1). Under the polarization of palladium, water molecules were cleaved to produce hydroxide ions (Int 2). Intramolecular transfer of hydroxide ions coordinated with palladium forms CS2‑hydroxy bridged metal complexes (Int 3). Subsequently, intramolecular fragmentation of this complex yielded COS (Int 4), which can then be released. COS underwent further reaction, recombining with palladium under the nucleophilic attack of hydroxyl groups to form Int 5. The subsequent cleavage of the Pd-O and C = S bonds lead to the formation of a sulfur ion-linked PAE-3 and carbon dioxide (Int 6). The catalyst was regenerated by nitric acid, enabling it to enter a new cycle. The capture of isotopically labeled carbonyl sulfur (C18OS) intermediates (Fig. 5a) and characterization of Pd-S bonds in the PAE-3 structure (Fig. 7a) corroborated this mechanism. The intermediates of the catalyzed reaction of the model complex HATN-Pd-1 were attempted to be captured in order to further confirm the potential intermediates and transition states in the catalytic reaction. NMR and mass spectrometry were used to fully characterize HATN-Pd-1 (Figures S24-S25). Fresh samples were taken out of the reaction mixture, and mass spectrometry in DMSO solution was used to determine the results. As shown in Figure S26, intermediate of [(HATN)Pd3S3+2H++HS−]+ and [(HATN)Pd2(NO3 −)4Pd(COS2)2−+H ++CH3CN]+ were observed at 831.7 and 1084.2, respectively. The observed intermediates were closely associated with the molecular conformation proposed in the putative mechanism, which favorably supported the above mechanism. Due to the exceptional stability and chemical resistance of palladium-functionalized polyarylethers, PAE-2 demonstrated robust cyclic catalytic performance. Even after a minimum of eight cycles, there was no significant decline in the efficiency of catalytic hydrolysis of carbon disulfide (Fig. 7d). This underscores the superiority of polyarylether heterogeneous catalysts and is of significant importance for the practical application of carbon disulfide removal at room temperature. 4 Conclusion In this study, we designed and synthesized a palladium-functionalized polymer based on polyarylether and established an efficient heterogeneous catalytic system for hydrolysis desulfurization. PAE-2, featuring palladium nitrate as the active catalytic center, facilitated the removal of carbon disulfide at room temperature. The reaction rate for the catalytic hydrolysis of carbon disulfide reached 6.54 μmol/g/h, while that for carbonyl sulfur was 27.24 μmol/g/h within a 10.5 h period. Employing nitric acid as a sacrificial agent enabled the catalyst to enhance and restore its activity, thus addressing the challenge of homogeneous catalyst regeneration. Over eight cycles, the heterogeneous catalyst demonstrated structural stability and outstanding catalytic desulfurization performance. This work introduces a novel platform for the room-temperature hydrolysis of carbon disulfide and offers valuable insights into the removal of contaminants from water using functionalized polymers. coredata.dc:description: The development of low-energy catalysts is crucial for addressing the challenge of removing carbon disulfide contamination. This study presents a Pd(II)-anchored polyarylether where numerous nitrogen atoms coordinate with palladium nitrate. The catalyst demonstrated remarkable activity against carbon disulfide at room temperature. Furthermore, the integration of chemically stable polymers and sacrificial agents enhanced the catalyst's renewability. By synthesizing both experimental and theoretical results, we proposed a reaction pathway whereby hydroxyl nucleophiles attacked the C = S bonds, leading to the formation of carbon dioxide. This research offered significant insights into the pivotal role of immobilized palladium in the hydrolysis of carbon disulfide and underscored the potential of polymers in purifying water from contaminants.
